description: The essential commands for version control.

slides.title: What is Git? üå≤
slides.content:
# Version Control

Git is a distributed version control system.

It tracks changes in your files, so you can:
- Revert to previous versions
- Collaborate with others
- Experiment without fear

slides.title: git init
slides.content:
# Start Here üèÅ

Initialize a new Git repository in your current directory.

`git init`

Creates a hidden `.git` folder where all the magic is stored.

slides.title: The Workflow üîÑ
slides.content:
# Three Stages

1. **Working Directory:** Where you edit files.
2. **Staging Area (Index):** Where you prepare changes (`git add`).
3. **Repository (HEAD):** Where changes are saved (`git commit`).

slides.title: git status
slides.content:
# Check In üìã

See `git status` at any time.

Tells you:
- Which files are modified.
- Which files are staged.
- Which branch you are on.

slides.title: git add
slides.content:
# Stage Changes üì¶

Move changes from Working Directory to Staging Area.

`git add file.txt` (Stage one file)
`git add .` (Stage all changes)

Think of it as "boxing up" your changes before shipping.

slides.title: Command Quiz
slides.quizQuestion: Which command moves changes from your working directory to the staging area?

slides.title: git commit
slides.content:
# Save Snapshot üì∏

Permanently save the staged changes to the repository.

`git commit -m "Fixed login bug"`

Always write a clear, descriptive message!

slides.title: git log
slides.content:
# History üìú

View the history of commits.

`git log` shows Author, Date, and Message.
`git log --oneline` shows a concise summary.

slides.title: git diff
slides.content:
# What changed? üîç

See the specific lines that have changed.

`git diff` (Unstaged changes)
`git diff --staged` (Staged changes vs last commit)

Uses `+` and `-` to show additions and deletions.

slides.title: .gitignore
slides.content:
# Ignore Rules üôà

A file named `.gitignore` tells Git which files to intentionally ignore.

(e.g., `node_modules/`, `.env`, `*.log`).

These files will not be tracked or committed.

slides.title: Identity Config
slides.content:
# Who are you? üÜî

Configure your name and email so commits are attributed to you.

`git config --global user.name "John Doe"`
`git config --global user.email "john@example.com"`

slides.title: Snapshot Quiz
slides.quizQuestion: What is required every time you create a commit?

slides.title: Summary
slides.content:
# Recap: Git Basics üå≤

Save your work.

- **init:** Start.
- **add:** Stage.
- **commit:** Save.
- **status:** Check.
- **log:** History.
